div.style: margin: 0px; padding: 0px; user-select: text; -webkit-user-drag: none; -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent; overflow: visible; cursor: text; clear: both; position: relative; direction: ltr; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-size: 12px;

span.br:
Please review the FAQ's below in regards to the CNUSD's response to COVID-19 school closures. Additional FAQ's are segmented by topic below.
Will CNUSD still be required to work during school closures?

p.span:
Only “essential” employees will need to report to work, and will be notified by their supervisor.
Are certificated employees deemed essential employees?
As of March 24, 2020 CNUSD has deemed all certificated staff members, both classroom teachers and support staff, as essential employees. At this time, all essential employees must be available remotely during regular work hours by email and for the foreseeable future as we work collaboratively to provide continuity of learning for as long as these school closures continue.

$(document).ready(function () {

                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl14_divTabs_0","title":"Payroll FAQ","content":"
Will Teachers continue to get paid during the duration of the closure?\n
Yes, teachers will continue to get paid including benefits during the duration of the closures.\n

\nI left my time card at the site and it wasn’t signed, how will it get to payroll and will I still get paid? How do I turn in my time card if the DO will be closed for three weeks? 
\nTime Cards can be dropped through the mail slot of the front doors of the District Office. Please make certain they are signed. We will remain flexible with time, but request the below dates for submission be followed, as we will be limited in processing time. \n
If this is a substitute time card – please drop them off by April 7th to be paid for the April 10th Payroll. This allows time for signature. \n
If this is for additional hours for all permanent employees –please drop them off by April 10th for processing. 
\n
\n
\n\n
Will payroll still be processed on time? 
\nSupplemental Payroll on Wednesday, March 18th has been processed for on-time payment. All physical checks will be mailed to the address on file. If you have direct deposit, your direct deposit will be deposited on pay day. \n
Monthly Payroll will be processed for on-time payment. All physical checks will be mailed to the address on file. If you have direct deposit, your direct deposit will be deposited on pay day. 
\n 
\nWhat is going to happen to CNUSD Bus drivers who are contracted by First Student?  
\nThe District is working with all of our vendors, including First Student, to honor the contract that we have in place so our vendors do not suffer any financial hardship due to the schools closures.  
\n 
\nWhich assignments will continue to receive their regular rate of pay during school closures? 
\n• Temporary Specialist 
\n• Adult Education Teacher 
\n• ACP Teacher 
\n• Sold Prep 
\n• Stipends 
\n• Home Hospital Teacher 
\n• Classified Permanent Extra Hours 
\n• NYU Interns 
\n• 5% out of class and Temporary out class pay 
\n• Noon Supervisor 
\n• AVID Tutor 
\n• Substitutes working in a long-term assignment for 5 or more consecutive days in AESOP/Frontline as of 3/13/20.  
\n 
\nIf I was scheduled for a day-to-day assignment in AESOP/Frontline for any future dates, will I receive pay? 
\nNo, HR will work with the Payroll Department to determine any available sick leave to be paid out.  
\n 
\nCan I still apply for a column change? 
\nAll future monthly deadlines for column changes will remain in place. This month’s deadline date is March 23rd. Transcripts must be received using the District office drop box (mail slot) at the main entrance. Transcripts may be mailed; however, they will only be processed if mail service continues.  
\n 
\nI need a Verification of Employment (VOE) completed. Is the District still processing them? 
\nYes, only if they are received via fax at (951)736-5077. ","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl14_divTabs_1","title":"Certificated Updated FAQ","content":"
School Closure MOU Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
\n
\nHas the District been communicating with CNTA regarding the school closures?\n
 \n\n    
Yes. Immediately upon initial school closures the District requested dates of availability from CNTA for bargaining impacts and effects of school closures. The District did not receive any dates in response to this request.\n\n\n    
On the evening of Friday, March 20, 2020 the District received a Demand to Bargain with a signed MOU prior to any discussions with the District. Within the demand to bargain, the District was told not to take action, plan for, or engage in communications with employees regarding the provision of distance learning.\n    
The District rejected this demand because it is the District’s exclusive responsibility to determine the types and levels of services that it offers. The District was required by the Governor’s Office to provide distance learning and/or other enrichment opportunities to students. In response to the Governor’s directives, the District began preparing and planning to comply.The District also had the responsibility to inform all stakeholders – parents, students, and employees – that it was developing and making distance learning opportunities available.\n    
On Sunday, March 22, 2020 CNTA issued the District a Cease and Desist with language that demonstrated a misunderstanding of the District’s authority and obligations during the State of Emergency.\n    
On Monday, March 23, 2020 the District responded to CNTA’s Demand to Bargain.\n    
On Tuesday, March 24, 2020, the District sent all certificated staff members notification regarding essential employee status.\n    
On the evening of Tuesday, March 24, 2020 certificated employees received inaccurate information that incorrectly suggested the District was proposing to stop compensation and fringe benefits during the school closures.
\n    On March 25, 2020 the District sent a memo to Certificated staff ensuring them of following:\n    
Pursuant to Executive Order N-26-20 and SB117, District employees will continue to receive their regular pay during the school closures.
\n    
\n    \n\n
Are teachers considered essential employees under the Executive Orders Issued by the Governor or any other law?\n
Yes.  Governor Newsom issued Executive Order N-26-20 on March 13, 2020 in which he ordered, among other things, that school districts provide distance learning opportunities.  See Governor’s Executive Order.    In response to the Governor’s State of Emergency, K-12 districts are mandated to deliver essential services to the public including the delivery of “distance learning.”  Teachers are critical to compliance with this mandate.  Accordingly, CNUSD established teachers as essential employees. The District issued a letter to teachers on March 24th with this information.\n
Will the District continue to communicate with staff and the community regarding any developments related to instruction and school opening?\n
Yes. As a public agency that delivers essential services, public schools have an obligation and duty under the Governor’s emergency order to communicate with the community during a state of emergency to convey how the District will be responding to the Governor’s mandates.\n

\nHas the District moved forward with distance learning beyond providing enrichment?
\nNo. Under conditions set forth by; the Governor’s State of Emergency, Executive Order for Public Schools, and guidance from CDE, CNUSD responded accordingly by activating plans to meet state mandates; namely, the planning and coordination of meal deliveries and distance learning (enrichment). With respect to distance learning, which the District defined as “enrichment only,” the District established and communicated the CNUSD Enrichment Website to stakeholders. \n
If teachers choose to use their personal devices will they be monitored by the District?
\nNo, CNUSD will not be monitoring internet use on personal devices. Moreover, the District does not have the ability to monitor anything outside of the District's network. We have full trust and confidence that our teachers will use professional discretion as it relates to our board policies regarding the appropriate use of technology and devices and communication with students. While it is not mandated to utilize a District device, the utilization of a District provided device \"DPD\" will allow for additional remote technical support from Information Technology Services. Teachers must abide by the District’s Employee Use of Technology – Responsible Use Policy.\n
Will teachers be expected to report to a district site during the closures?
\nNo. The health and safety of our teachers is critically important to us. We are in full support of our teachers adhering to the state-wide “stay at home” order issued by the Governor. Therefore, teachers will not be required to report to a site unless it is on their own accord to retrieve personal or professional items from their classroom—all site visits during the closure will need to abide by current public health social distancing guidelines (no more than 10 people at 6 feet apart). If you would like to retrieve personal or professional items from your classroom, please contact your site principal to schedule a time. Staff will not be required to report back to the site until the closure is lifted and sites have been thoroughly cleaned and disinfected.\n
How will grading work during the closures?\n
Students will be held \"harmless,\" and will not receive a lesser grade than their current grade as a result of engaging in Distance Learning during this unprecedented time. This aligns with the State Superintendent of Public Instructions' recent statements that assessments should not be used during this time as a summative measure, but rather as a formative measure to gauge instruction and determine where students need support. Students will, however, be able to earn a higher grade as a result of engaging in Distance Learning, and if appropriate, may be assigned to credit recovery. More information regarding this topic will be forthcoming.\n
Will Teachers continue to get paid during the duration of the closure?
\nYes, teachers will continue to get paid including benefits during the duration of the closure.\n
 What does working the professional day mean?
\nThe professional day is intended to provide a great deal of flexibility. There is no expectation to work a continuous set of hours. The hours worked should not exceed regular work hours. The work day is the accumulation of all time spent preparing, planning, posting, grading, holding office hours, etc.
\n
\nIs there an expectation for teachers to be readily available during regular school hours?
\nNo. There is not a requirement for teachers to be available for a continuous set of hours. However, during regular office hours, teachers need to be available and responsive to inquiries from students and parents. Each unit member is responsible for setting a schedule that support the completion of their professional duty.
\n
\nWhat is the expectation for office hours?
\nIt is expected that regular office hours are set, scheduled, and posted each week. Office hour availability should reflect a reasonable amount of time needed to support students related to the scope and amount of enrichment being assigned to students. This time is intended for interacting directly with students and/or parents. The methods for interaction are flexible and may include exchanging emails, Google voice/phone calls, or other digital platforms. In order to accommodate for the flexibility needed for students and parents, it may be helpful to schedule office hours at least twice a week, like Monday and Wednesday from 10-11 am OR Tuesday 8-9 am and Thursday 2-3 pm.
\n
\nAdministrators will also offer regular office hours to provide an opportunity for students, parents, and unit members to interact directly to receive support and clarification during the school closure.
\n
\nHow do I satisfy the need of posting my office hours?
\nOffice hours should be regularly scheduled and communicated to students and parents. This can be accomplished by posting via electronic means, including but not limited to email, teacher website, Google Classroom, Twitter, Class Dojo, Remind, etc. Also, regularly schedule office hours, or changes to your office hour schedule, should be communicated to the site principal. Site admin may request this information from their teachers via email, survey, or some other means.
\n
\nWhat meetings will unit members be required to participate in during school closure?
\nUnit members shall make every attempt to attend staff meeting when scheduled in order to obtain updated and accurate information during the school closure. It is expected that meetings are scheduled in advance, during the regular work day, and in accordance with the CBA.
\nIf unit members are unable to attend the live staff meeting, it is expected they will view the recorded meeting at their earliest opportunity. If a unit member is unclear or has questions related to the information shared in the recorded staff meeting, the unit member shall contact their site administrator for clarification.
\nWhile unit members are encouraged to collaborate with their colleagues, when possible, there is no requirement to attend any other meetings, including but not limited to PCT, Department Chair, Grade Level Teams, PBIS Teams, Leadership Team, etc.
\n
\nWhat is the expectation related Special Education services and IEPs?
\nWe continue to receive updated information from the CDE related to Special Education services during school closures. The District and CNTA will continue to collaborate on the
\nimplementation on any new guidance from the CDE related to Special Education during these school closures. Special Education unit members are expected to provide support and/or enrichment for students in their area of expertise.
\n
\nWhat information can be provided regarding grading?
\nWe will provided further updates prior to April 13th. 
\n
\nAm I subjecting myself to any liability related to accessing, sharing, or participating in digital learning?
\nUnit members should always practice responsible decision making within the scope of their employment and be aware the internet is a fluid platform. Unit members will not be liable if students or others access content that is not directly provided through instruction. Unit members are covered under the district’s liability protection when they are operating under the scope of their employment. If unit members are uncomfortable utilizing any non-district digital platforms, unit members are not required to do so.
\n
\nIn addition, unit members are not responsible or liable for the misconduct of students or other participant during distance learning. All misconduct must be reported to the unit member’s site administrator. Unit members may provide alternative opportunities for students that are unable to be appropriate participants. If a unit member takes this action, a site administrator shall be notified.
\n
\nHow will I be informed about upcoming professional development related to Distance Learning?
\nAll voluntary training topics and dates will be emailed to all unit members early this week. Unit members participating in the voluntary trainings during non-duty/off-track time will not be expected to submit a time card. List of participants will be provided to payroll and HR. Unit members will be paid the curriculum rate according to established payroll timelines.
\n
\nWhat options do our students have if they left their textbooks at school prior to the school closure?
\nThe District will maintain the enrichment website for students and teachers as a resource. Teachers should feel free to find and utilize supplemental resources to help plan enrichment. More information to come about additional resources.\n
 \n
What was the reason for a delay in cancelling open houses during the earlier reports regarding the COVID-19 pandemic?
\nWithout any confirmed COVID-19 cases, the Riverside County Department of Public Health guidance did not support the cancellation of school activities or events prior to March 12, 2020. CNUSD consulted with the Department of Public Health and followed their recommendations, as they are the lead agency in matters related to public health crises.  On March 12, 2020 the order from the Governor and public health officials advised that events should be cancelled if they meet certain criteria. See letter from the District here.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl14_divTabs_2","title":"Absences | Leaves | Dr. Notes | TB Notices FAQ","content":"
I have preplanned non-duty days scheduled for spring break. What happens to those days? 
\nAll current employee calendars remain in effect. Information is currently being gathered on how requests for changes to calendars will be handled during the time of the school closures. Once we have the proper clarifications, HR will communicate those out. 
\n
\n\n
I have an updated doctor's note returning me to work or placing me off work.  Whom do I contact? 
\nPlease submit any doctor’s note to the email address: immunizations@cnusd.k12.ca.us.  \n
If the note returns an employee without restriction, then the employee will be reinstated per the return date on the doctor's note. \n
If the note returns an employee with restriction, then Ben Roberts (Certificated) or Kathy Lee (Classified) will review the restrictions prior to any return being granted. \n
If the restriction(s), in normal conditions prior to the school closure:  \n\n    
Can be reasonably accommodated, the employee will be restored back to a working status. \n    
Cannot be reasonably accommodated, then an interactive meeting will be initiated via phone call.  Based on the interactive meeting, the employee may or may not be restored back to a working status. \n    
 \n\n
Do I need to report illness/PN?  If so, how? 
\nEssential Employees who have been called back to work: \n
Yes. Report your absence to your supervisor.  \n
What if I am uncomfortable reporting to work? \n\n    
All applicable emergency directive orders will be applied to the request. \n\n
Employees who have not been called back to work site: \n
No. There is no need to report an absence as you are not required to report to work at this time. 
\n
\n\n
I am currently on a pregnancy/maternity leave.  How do the school closures affect my leave? 
\nAll employees currently on FMLA or CFRA leave will continue in their current status. 
\n
\n\n
Does bereavement leave still apply during school closures? 
\nThis leave is applicable for those essential employees who have been called back to work.  All conditions of this leave still apply. 
\n
\n\n
I am currently on Industrial leave.  How do the school closures affect this leave? 
\nAny changes need to be based on an updated report/doctor's note from the treating physician.  Please email Tracy Payne, Risk Management, at tpayne@cnusd.k12.ca.us. 
\n
\n\n
I am an Essential Employee called back to my work site.  What steps do I take if I am injured?  How do I report my injury? 
\nCall Company Nurse at (877)518-6712 AND email Tracy Payne, Risk Management, at tpayne@cnusd.k12.ca.us. 
\n
\n
\n\n
What happens if I have a summons for jury duty? 
\nWe have been informed that all courts have postponed jury duty at this time.  We suggest you follow up with the assigning court for further direction.   \n
I am in one of the branches of the military.  What happens if I am placed on active duty during the school closures? 
\nEmail your orders to immunizations@cnusd.k12.ca.us so we can process this leave.\n
I am currently in an unpaid leave.  How do the school closures affect my status? 
\nThe terms of an unpaid leave will remain in effect as determined prior to our school closure. \n
I have Vacation days (Classified) or Non-Duty days (Certificated) scheduled during the school closure dates.  Am I able to make any changes or adjustments to the days? 
\nAll previously approved vacation and non-duty days will remain in effect as determined prior to our school closure. \n
I received a notice from Human Resources indicating my TB is about to expire.  I am concerned about going into a medical facility at this time.  What are my options?  
\nIf you already visited a physician and need to submit your TB certification, please submit any documentation to immunizations@cnusd.k12.ca.us.  \n
If you have not obtained TB certification at this time, we are seeking legal guidance on our ability to provide a local options and/or temporary waiver.  More information to come. \n
Disclaimer: All leaves are subject to current, and any future, statutory legal guidance that may occur during the course of the school closures.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl14_divTabs_3","title":"Mental Health Resources","content":"Self-Care and more","active":false,"disabled":false}],// required,
                        propPaneId: 'paneId', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propTitle: 'title', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propActive: 'active', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes

                        propContent: 'content', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        tabMode : tabM,
                        scrollToTabEdge: false, // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        disableScrollArrowsOnFullyScrolled: false // optional- pass in default value for demo purposes
                    }).on('ready.scrtabs', function() {
                        $('#'+this.id+' .tab-pane').attr('tabindex',0);
                    });
                };

                activate();
            }
        }
    });

div.p: The Corona Norco Unified School District is committed to equal opportunity for all individuals in education and in employment and does not discriminate on the basis of actual or perceived ancestry, age, color, disability, gender, gender identity, gender expression, nationality, immigration status, race or ethnicity, religion, sex, sexual orientation, pregnancy, parental/marital or family status, primary language, social class, geographical location, or association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics. The Board prohibits, at any district school or school activity, unlawful discrimination, harassment, intimidation, and bullying of any student based on the protected characteristics named above. (CNUSD BP300, BP1321, BP4190, BP/AR4301, BP5145, BP5146, BP/AR5208)

td.span: For any concerns or questions regarding discrimination, equity, Title II, CCR Title 5 or Title IX, please contact:
For any allegations under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, please contact:

div.p: Pupils have the right to a free public education, regardless of immigration status or religious beliefs. More information about these rights is available from the California Attorney General, Know Your Rights

div.span: Website by SchoolMessenger Presence. © 2020 Intrado Corporation. All rights reserved.

li.span: Other staff, login at your school website
